“ Oṁ, Great Wrath! Please enter! Hūṁ hūṁ hūṁ, āḥ! You are the holder of the terrible vajra surrounded by a halo of flames. Āḥ! Skt., oṁ praviśa krodha hūṁ hūṁ hūṁ āḥ | jvālāmālākulabhīṣaṇavajra āḥ.
“As soon as this mantra is uttered, he will become able to effect the ‘external’ possession, the summoning, and the humbling. [22.25]
“Next in the great sovereign Bhūtaḍāmara Tantra are the detailed instructions on the ritual of the maṇḍala of Great Wrath.
“The mantra of Siṃhadhvajadhāriṇī, who is located in front of Great Wrath:
“ Oṁ, bhūḥ! Glorious Siṃhadhvajadhāriṇī! Hrīḥ! Skt., oṁ bhūḥ śrīsiṃhadhvajadhāriṇi hrīḥ. [22.26]
“The mantra of Padmāvatī, who is behind Great Wrath:
“ Oṁ, hūṁ, bhūṁ! The great Padmāvatī, holding an arrow and bow! Hūṁ! Skt., oṁ hūṁ bhūṁ mahāpadmāvati dhanurbāṇadhāriṇi hūṁ. [22.27]
“The mantra of Vibhūti, who is to the right of Great Wrath:
“ Oṁ, hūṁ! Vibhūti, holding a goad! Hūṁ, jaḥ! Skt., oṁ hūṁ vibhūti aṅkuśadhāriṇi hūṁ jaḥ. [22.28]
“The mantra of Surahāriṇī, who is to the left of Great Wrath:
“ Oṁ, hūṁ, bhūḥ! Surahāriṇī, holding a banner surmounted by a wish-fulfilling gem! Śrūṃ! Skt., oṁ hūṁ bhūḥ surahāriṇi cintāmaṇidhvajadhāriṇi śrūṃ. [22.29]
“The mantra for the northeast: The Tib. has “In the northeast, flower.”
“ Oṁ, Glorious Vārāhī, with a flower in her hand! Hūṁ! Skt., oṁ śrīvarāhiṇi puṣpahaste hūṁ. [22.30]
“The mantra for incense, in the southeast:
“ Oṁ, Ratneśvarī, with incense in her hand! Hūṁ! Skt., oṁ ratneśvari dhūpahaste hūṁ. [22.31]
“The mantra for perfume, in the southwest:
“ Oṁ, glorious Vibhūṣaṇī, with perfume in her hand! Hūṁ! Skt., oṁ śrībhūṣaṇi gandhahaste hūṁ. [22.32]
“The mantra for lamp, in the northwest:
“ Oṁ, glorious Jagatpālinī, with a lamp in her hand! Āḥ! Skt., oṁ śrījagatpālini dīpahaste āḥ. [22.33]
“Next are the detailed instructions on the mudrās of the eight bhūtinīs.
“The mudrā of the lion banner:
“Hold your fists together and extend both index fingers. [22.34]

“The mudrā of the goad: In the Tib. the order is different; after the mudrā of the lion banner comes the mudrā of the banner surmounted by the wish-fulfilling gem, then the mudrā of the arrow and bow, and then mudrā of the goad.
“Form your right hand into a fist and extend your index finger, bending it slightly. [22.35]
“The mudrā of the arrow and bow:

“Holding your fists together, extend your index fingers and place your fists on your left hip. The Tib. has “One should place the same mudrā on the hip.” “The same mudrā” refers to the “banner surmounted with the wish-fulfilling gem,” which in the Tibetan comes before the “arrow and bow.” [22.36] [F.260.b]
“The mudrā of the banner surmounted by a wish-fulfilling gem:
“Form your left hand into a fist while extending your middle finger. [22.37]
“The mudrā of the flower:
“Join your hands together with fingers outstretched and then slightly bend both index fingers. [22.38]
“The mudrā of incense:
“Entwine your fingers and extend both index fingers. [22.39]
“The mudrā of perfume:
“Stretch out both hands and place them on your shoulders. [22.40]
“The mudrā of the lamp:
“Form your right hand into a fist while extending the middle finger.” [22.41]
div.trailer: This concludes the chapter from the great sovereign “Bhūtaḍāmara Tantra” that contains detailed instructions on the ritual of the maṇḍala of King Wrath.

div.head: Chapter 23
div.p: Next follows the chapter from the great sovereign Bhūtaḍāmara Tantra that contains detailed instructions on the sādhanas of the eight bhūtas.
[Their mantras are:]

Aparājita: Oṁ hrīḥ jaḥ!
Ajita: Oṁ hūṁ jaḥ!
Pūraṇa: Oṁ hrīḥ jaḥ!
Āpūraṇa: Oṁ hūṁ jaḥ!
Śmaśānādhipati: Oṁ śrūṃ jaḥ!
Kuleśvara: Oṁ rūṃ jaḥ!
Bhūteśvara: Oṁ hūṁ jaḥ!
Kiṃkarottama: Oṁ āṃ jaḥ! [23.1]
“The sādhana of the bhūta Aparājita:

“One should recite the mantra in front of Vajradhara The Tib. has “One should go to a shrine of Vajradhara.” 100,000 times. This constitutes the preliminary practice. Then, on the full moon day, one should prepare an elaborate pūjā and offer cooked white rice, curds, molasses, and milk The Tib. adds honey and meat to this list. as prescribed. Burning bdellium incense, one should recite all night. Aparājita is certain to arrive at dawn. If he does not arrive, he will die right then. Once he arrives, he will request orders, saying ‘What can I do?’ The Tib. has “Once he arrives, he should not be given trivial commands.” The practitioner should reply, ‘Please be my servant.’ From then on he will perform the duties of a servant. He will offer the kingdom of the vidyādharas and will eliminate all one’s enemies. He will even bring the goddess Śaśī and offer her. Taking the practitioner upon his back, he will carry him to the realm of the gods, where he will bestow upon him the status of Indra. The practitioner will live for seven eons. [23.2]
“The sādhana of Ajita:

“Standing in front of a caitya, The Tib. follows manuscript G in reading daitya instead of caitya. The Tibetan term appears in the feminine (sbyin byed ma) despite the fact that daityas (a class of asuras) are typically male. The reading daitya is unlikely, as Ajita is not one of them. one should recite the mantra one thousand and eight times at night for seven days. On the seventh day one should prepare an elaborate pūjā and offer bali. Burning bdellium incense, [F.261.a] one should recite the mantra. Ajita is certain to arrive at the end of the recitation. He will say, ‘Hey practitioner! What can I do for you?’ The practitioner should reply, ‘Please be my servant.’ Ajita, taking him upon his back, will carry him around the four continents. Furthermore, he will give him a kingdom. The practitioner will live one thousand The Tib. has “five thousand.” years. [23.3]
“The sādhana of Pūraṇa:

“One should go to a temple of Vajradhara and recite the mantra one thousand and eight times for seven days. On the seventh day one should prepare an elaborate pūjā and offer cooked white rice and curds as prescribed. One should recite the mantra until midnight, when Pūraṇa is certain to arrive. One should give him a welcome offering of water with flowers. He will be pleased, offer a kingdom, and completely fulfill one’s every wish. One will live thousands of years, and for as long as one lives Pūraṇa will perform the duties of a servant. He can be induced to kill anyone or let them live. He can do anything. [23.4]
“The sādhana of Āpūraṇa:

“One should go to a caitya that contains relics and recite the mantra ten thousand times. This constitutes the preliminary practice. Then, on the day of the full moon, one should offer a pūjā according to one’s means and recite the mantra until midnight, at which time Āpūraṇa will swiftly arrive. When he arrives, he will stand in front of one and say, ‘What can I do for you, my dear?’ The practitioner should reply, ‘Please be my servant,’ and from then on he will perform the duties of a servant. He will bring a divine yakṣa maiden and offer her, disclose the location of every treasure hoard, and will offer delicious divine food. Every day he will offer a pair of garments The Tib. has “a pair of red garments.” and five dinars. The practitioner will live five hundred years. [23.5]
“The sādhana of Śmaśānādhipati: The Tib. has, “Next is the detailed explanation of the sādhana ritual of Śmaśānādhipati.”

“One should go at night to a charnel ground and recite the mantra one thousand and eight times for seven days. On the seventh day one should follow the prescribed rite to offer fish, meat, sesame, and rose apple cooked white rice, curds, molasses, and milk to this great bhūta. The sequence in the Tib. is “On the seventh day one should follow the prescribed rite to offer meat, fish, sesame, rose apple, balls made of three sweets mixed together, and chopped horse meat. One grills and fries these substances in butter. One should offer cooked rice, curd, molasses, milk rice porridge, pulse, and fried pastries...” [F.261.b] One should recite the mantra until midnight while burning bdellium incense. Then, the sound hā hā will be heard. One should not be afraid—Śmaśānādhipati has arrived with his retinue. One should offer bali to this visitor. He will be pleased, and all the bhūtas will become one’s servants. Śmaśānādhipati will offer eight dinars every day and will crush all one’s enemies. One will live a thousand The Tib. has “five thousand.” years. [23.6]
“The sādhana of Kuleśvara:

“One should go to a temple and, after offering red perfumes, red flowers, and bdellium incense, recite the mantra ten thousand times. This constitutes the preliminary practice. At night, on the fourteenth day of the dark fortnight, one should prepare fish, meat, sesame, rose apple, and cooked red rice as prescribed. Burning frankincense, The Tib. has “one should offer frankincense and flowers.” one should recite until midnight. Kuleśvara will then arrive in a terrible, blazing form, but one should not be afraid of him. He will say, ‘What can I do for you, my dear?’ The practitioner should reply, ‘Please be my servant.’ He will then perform the duties of a servant for as long as the practitioner lives. This sentence is missing from the Tib. Every day, three times a day, he will offer five dinars and delicious divine food. The practitioner will live five hundred years. The Tib. has “five thousand.” [23.7]
“The sādhana of Bhūteśvara:

“One should go alone at night to a solitary Śiva liṅga and, for three days, offer cooked red rice, fish, meat, sesame, and rose apple. While burning incense made of goat meat and bdellium mixed with honey, In the Tib. has “...one should offer a bali comprised of cooked red rice, fish, and meat. While burning incense made of goat meat, bdellium, and honey...” one should recite the mantra one thousand and eight times. On the first day one will see Bhūteśvara in dream. On the second day Bhūteśvara will promptly arrive in person and stand in front of the practitioner. The Tibetan has “On the second day one will see him directly. On the third day he will swiftly arrive and stand before the practitioner.” He will say, ‘What can I do for you?’ The practitioner should reply, ‘Please be my servant.’ Bhūteśvara will remains in close attendance. He will bring an apsaras and offer her, Instead of “He will bring an apsaras and offer her,” the Tib. has “He will offer an inexhaustible treasure.” and will describe the past, present, and future. He will give clothes, adornments, and delicious divine foods. [F.262.a] The practitioner will live for three hundred years. The Tib. has “two thousand years.” [23.8]
“The sādhana of Kiṃkarottama:

“One should go to a temple of Vajradhara on the fourteenth day of the dark fortnight and recite the mantra ten thousand times for seven days. This constitutes the preliminary practice. Then one should burn bdellium incense Before “burn bdellium incense,” the Tib. adds “prepare a sandalwood maṇḍala.” and offer cooked white rice, ghee, and milk. The Tib. includes “white flowers” in this list of offerings. Sitting on a seat of kuśa grass, one should light a butter lamp and recite the mantra into the night until, at midnight, Kiṃkarottama arrives in person. Upon arrival, he should be given a welcome offering of water scented with white sandalwood. He will be pleased and say, ‘Hey practitioner! What can I do for you?’ The practitioner should reply, ‘Please be my servant.’ From then on, Kiṃkarottama will perform the duties of a servant and will offer delicious divine food. The Tib. adds here “elixirs of longevity and power substances and will lead one to treasures.” Taking the practitioner on his back, he will take him to the heavenly realm. Moreover, he will give him a kingdom and a lifespan of five thousand years.” “A lifespan of five thousand years” is missing from the Tib. [23.9]
div.trailer: This concludes the chapter from the great sovereign “Bhūtaḍāmara Tantra” that contains detailed instructions on the sādhanas for servants.

div.head: Chapter 24
div.p: “For the benefit of spiritual instructors I will now explain, just as it has been taught, the sādhana for servants that produces manifold accomplishments. No one among those one should not generally associate with is to be forsaken, including idlers and evildoers, liars, loafers, the poor and diseased, those with short lives, and those with restless minds. If one wants enjoyments, wealth, and fame, these will be instantly and abundantly given. This translation of this passage relies heavily on the Tib. because the Skt. is corrupt and differs markedly between manuscripts. [24.1]

“This magical mantra can win the elixir of long life that is precious to the lord of gods, so it certainly can win treasures from human kings. The Tib. has, “If by this mantra the elixir of long life and the kingdom of the gods can be attained, what need is there to mention the attainment of the kingdoms of humans?” Likewise, it can instantly win a celestial maiden. When this magical mantra is recited, it quickly and easily produces accomplishments. These exceedingly secret four syllables that grant every comfort will grant all accomplishments to innumerable beings of inferior diligence. [F.262.b] They will be attained after only a single recitation, there is no doubt about this.” [24.2]
div.trailer: This concludes the chapter from the great sovereign “Bhūtaḍāmara Tantra” that contains detailed instructions on the sādhana for magical accomplishments.

div.head: Chapter 25
div.p: Next follow the descriptions of the mudrās of the eight bhūtas from the great sovereign Bhūtaḍāmara Tantra.
“The mudrā of Aparājita, the great king:
“Fold in the fingers of both hands while extending your middle fingers to form the shape of a needle. [25.1]
“The mudrā of Ajita:
“Forming the above mudrā, fold in your middle fingers and extend your index fingers while slightly bending them. [25.2]
“The mudrā of Pūraṇa:
“Forming the same mudrā as above, curl your index fingers into a semicircle The Tib. has “curl the left index finger.” and extend the little fingers, holding them apart. [25.3]
“The mudrā of Āpūraṇa:
“Forming the same mudrā, “Forming the same mudrā” is missing from the Tib. fold in the fingers of both hands. [25.4]
“The mudrā of Śmaśānādhipati:
“Forming the same mudrā, form your middle fingers into the shape of a needle. The Tib. has, “fold in your little fingers and thumbs.” [25.5]
“The mudrā of Bhūteśvara: This mudrā is missing from the Tib.
“Form the same mudrā, but hold both thumbs out to the side. [25.6]
“The mudrā of Kuleśvara:
“Forming the same mudrā, fold your thumbs inward and extend your little fingers, holding them apart. For the description of this mudrā, the Tib. only has “Fully extend your little fingers.” [25.7]
“The mudrā of Kiṃkarottama:
“Join the cupped palms of your hands together and slightly bend both index fingers.” [25.8]
div.trailer: This concludes the chapter from the great sovereign “Bhūtaḍāmara Tantra” that contains the descriptions of the mudrās of the eight bhūtas. The Tib. has “eight great bhūtas kings.”

div.head: Chapter 26
div.p: Then Vajrapāṇi, the master of guhyakas, Instead of “lord of guhyakas,” the Tib. has “lord of mysteries.” said this to the lord: This translation follows the Skt., where bhagavān refers to Śiva. In the Tib., however, bhagavān qualifies Vajrapāṇi. The Tib. reads “Then, the lord Vajrapāṇi, master of guhyakas, said . . .”

“The preceding practice of bhūta-attendants is for the benefit of the vajra master. So is the following sādhana of the great bhūtinīs. The Tib. has “The vajra master should practice the bhūtinī named Śrīmahā, a sādhana for a female attendant, for the benefit to vajra masters.” Both will be thrilled, and joy will arise in the hearts of the bhūtinīs. [26.1]
“Next follow the detailed instructions on the sādhana of the glorious great bhūtinīs found in the great sovereign Bhūtaḍāmara Tantra.
“First, the detailed instructions for the gentle sādhana are:

“The practitioner should recite the mantra In manuscript A this mantra is given as śrī hūṁ. in front of the blessed lord Great Wrath 100,000 times. This constitutes the preliminary practice. Then, on the day of the full moon, he should offer a pūjā according to his means, burn bdellium incense, and recite the mantra all night. A bhūtinī is certain to arrive at dawn. Upon her arrival, he should give her a welcome offering of sandalwood-scented water and say, ‘Welcome!’ She will reply, ‘Hey practitioner, what do you command me to do?’ He should say, ‘Please be my wife.’ [F.263.a] She will offer a divine elixir of long life, power substances, treasures, and a kingdom. [26.2]
“There are also forceful sādhanas:

“The practitioner should draw the glorious bhūtinī on birch bark with saffron ink. “With saffron ink” is missing from the Tib. Then at night, he should recite the mantra one thousand and eight times while naked in front of Vajradhara. She will swiftly arrive. He should make love to her as soon as she arrives and she will be pleased. She will offer him a kingdom The Tib. has “She will offer sovereignty over the triple world.” and even raise him to the status of Indra. Taking him on her back, she will take him to heavenly realms. He will live one thousand The Tib. has “ten thousand.” years. If she does not comply she will, at that very moment, burst at the forehead, wither, and die. The line “This has been said by Great Wrath himself,” that ends the following passage in the Skt. concludes the preceding passage in the Tib. The following passage is not found in the Tib. [26.3]
“Next are the detailed instructions for killing all bhūtinīs.

“The practitioner should perform the rites of killing and castigation in the center of the maṇḍala that was previously described. The bhūtinī will be killed in an instant. This has been said by Great Wrath himself. [26.4]

“The practitioner should write a bhūtinī’s name with saffron. Then, stepping over it with his left foot and raising the vajra-scepter, he should repeat the syllable hūṁ
The Tib. has hūṁ, hūṁ, phaṭ, phaṭ.
seven times. He is certain to kill her instantly.” [26.5]
div.trailer: This concludes the chapter from the great sovereign “Bhūtaḍāmara Tantra” that contains detailed instructions on the sādhana procedures.

div.head: Chapter 27
div.p: “Having summoned the spirits of divine origin, the practitioner should bow to them and then dismiss them. This sentence and the following mantra of invitation are missing from the Tib.
“The mantra for inviting the deities who are to partake of the offering:
“Wherever any great spirit is, may he leave that terrible place! Svāhā! Skt., yathā yathā mahābhūto raudrasthānaṃ pramuñcatu svāhā. [27.1]

“Having offered a bali of cooked red rice, flowers, and incense to the participating deities, the practitioner should cover it with a white cloth and recite the following mantra three times while bowing to and dismissing the spirits of divine origin: The Tib. contains only the following line prior to the mantra: “One should burn bdellium incense, set out a bali covered with a white cloth, and recite the mantra three times.” The phrase “bowing to and dismissing the spirits of divine origin” is rendered in Sanskrit phonetics and included in the mantra that follows.

“O great spirits, go to your respective abodes—to charnel grounds, shrines, solitary trees, riverbanks, crossroads, solitary Śiva liṅgas, or temples. Go quickly so you can keep your pledges of the spirits. If you do not go, your heads will be split with a thunderbolt, killing you in an instant. You will be dispatched to the terrible hell of spirits. Go to your respective places as you please! Svāhā!” Skt., yathā yathā mahābhūtasvasthānaṃ tatra gacchantu | śmaśāne devakuleṣu ekavṛkṣe nadītaṭe catuṣpathe ekaliṅge vā devāyataneṣu ca kṣipraṃ gacchantu bhūtānāṃ samayaṃ pratipālanāya | yadi caivaṃ na gacchanti vajreṇa mūrdhānaṃ sphālayet | kṣaṇena nāśayet | bhūtānāṃ raurave narake patet | yathā yathā svasthānaṃ gacchata yathāsukham svāhā ||
The Tib. adds here, “Thus should the master address the gods.” [27.2]
div.trailer: This concludes the chapter from the great sovereign “Bhūtaḍāmara Tantra” that contains the detailed instructions on the bali offering. The Tibetan translation ends here. Instead of this chapter colophon, we have the following two colophons: “This concludes the second section of the great sovereign Bhūtaḍāmara Tantra,” followed by “This concludes the available portion of the sixteen thousandfold tantra known as Bhūtaḍāmara.” The Tibetan text then ends with the translators’ statement, “The tantra was translated, edited, and finalized by the Indian preceptor Buddhākaravarma and the lotsāwa monk Chökyi Sherab.”

div.head: Chapter 28
div.p: “The formula for dismissing the spirits after the bali offering:

q.p: “Please go back quickly to your charnel grounds, shrines, mountain tops, or crossroads! Skt., śmaśāne devakuleṣu parvatāgre catuṣpathe kṣipraṃ gacchantu. This formula seems to be a shorter alternative of the formula given in the last paragraph of the previous chapter. [28.1];

div.p: “The formula for the spirits to guard their pledges:

q.p: “Please keep your pledge! Skt., samaye tiṣṭhantu. [28.2]

div.p: “The mantras for summoning all deities and male and female spirits are:

“The reciter of Wrath is himself commanding you, please leave your terrible places! Svāhā! Skt., raudraṃ sthānaṃ pramuñcata svāhā.
Oṁ, unfailing vajra hook! Act, act! Pull, pull! Hūṁ jaḥ! Skt., oṁ amoghavajrāṅkuśa kara kara kaḍḍa kaḍḍa hūṁ jaḥ. [28.3]
“And:

“ Oṁ, fierce Wrath with an unfailing hook—act, act! Make such-and-such enter, do it! Hrīḥ, hūṁ, jaḥ! Skt., oṁ caṇḍakrodhāya amoghāṅkuśāya kara kara kaḍḍa kaḍḍa praveśaya praveśaya amukaṃ hrīḥ hūṁ jaḥ. [28.4]
“The mudrā of the hook:
“One should join both index fingers so that they form the shape of a hook. [28.5]
“One should offer a bali after incanting it with the following mantra three or seven times:
“ Oṁ, Vajra Wrath! Please take this bali! Hūṁ, phaṭ! Skt., oṁ vajrakrodha baliṃ gṛhṇa hūṁ phaṭ. [28.6]
“[One should then recite:]

“ Oṁ, hrīḥ! To Bhūtaḍāmara, the great vajra! Hūṁ hūṁ hūṁ! Ślūṃ ślūṃ! Hūṁ hūṁ! Phaṭ phaṭ! Svāhā! May the servant beings take whatever bali is available, body, speech, and mind! Svāhā! Skt., oṁ hrīḥ bhūtaḍāmaramahāvajrāya hūṁ hūṁ hūṁ ślūṃ ślūṃ hūṁ hūṁ phaṭ phaṭ svāhā | baliṃ gṛhṇantu ceṭakā yathāprāptiṃ kāyavākcittaḥ svāhā ||
It is not clear how “the body, speech, and mind” fit in with the rest of this mantra. [28.7]
“[The eighteen types of emptiness:]

item.p: 10. Emptiness of that which is beginningless and endless
11. Emptiness of that which cannot be repudiated
15. Emptiness of that which cannot be apprehended
16. Emptiness of that which has its own nature
17. Emptiness of that which does not have its own nature
18. Emptiness of that which has and does not have its own nature [28.8]

div.p: “The eight bhūtas are:

lg.l: “The bhūta-king Aparājita,
As well as Ajita and Pūraṇa;
The wild and fierce Āpūraṇa
And the great Śmaśānādhipati. [28.9]
“Kuleśvara, Bhūteśa, and also
Kiṃkarottama who carries out one’s orders.
In the tantra of Ḍāmara,
These eight great beings are called ‘servants.’ ” For want of a better word, kiṃkara is translated as “servant”; the precise meaning of this word is “one who is asking what to do.” [28.10]

div.trailer: This concludes the great sovereign “Bhūtaḍāmara Tantra.”
div.p: The Tathāgata has explained the causes of those phenomena that arise based on causes. The great monk also explained that which constitutes their cessation.
